etymology.description: ideogrammic: 亻 ‘person’ + 本 ‘basis’; in trad. 體: semantic 骨 ‘bone’ + phonetic 豐.
etymology.interpretation: Combines the idea of a person with a foundational base, pointing to one’s fundamental constitution and thus ‘body’, and by extension ‘form’ or ‘style’. In the traditional form, the ‘bone’ element underscores the bodily frame while 豐 supplies the sound, reinforcing a physical framework sense.
etymology.simplification: Simplified by replacing the phono-semantic 體 (骨 + 豐) with the more transparent and lower-stroke form 体 (亻 + 本), aligning meaning with ‘person’ and easing writing.

examples.chinese: 他的身体很健康(他的身體很健康)。
这款字体很优雅(這款字體很優雅)。
改革现有体制需要时间(改革現有體制需要時間)。
examples.english: Reforming the existing system takes time.
